Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: DIG Texas - A Workshop on Diversity and Innovation in Geosciences in Texas
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports a 2.5 day workshop that will bring together geoscientists and geoscience educators from 35 institutions of higher education located across the state of Texas, to discuss strategies for improving geosciences literacy among the state's K-12 student population. The project is a collaboration between Texas A&M University College of Geosciences, the University of Texas Jackson School of Geosciences, and the American Geophysical Union. The goals of the workshop are to: support teachers of a new high school capstone Earth and Space Science class being offered in Texas; increase appreciation and competency of Texas students and teachers regarding the geosciences; and, develop linkages among existing geosciences education programs, in order to promote synergy and multiply their impacts. The large minority (dominantly Hispanic) population within Texas offers an outstanding opportunity for broadening participation of underrepresented groups within the geosciences, through achievement of these goals. Anticipated outcomes of the workshop include a state-wide network of geoscientists and geoscience educators engaged in reforming and strengthening Earth science-related education and organized through regional hub institutions; a web site to facilitate state-wide communication; and a workshop report.

POR.DRECONTENT:
NSF Geo Ed Planning Grant Geo #1016032, DIG TEXAS, Project Outcomes

 DIG TEXAS (Diversity and Innovation for Geosciences in Texas), led by the Texas A&M University College of Geosciences and The University of Texas (UT) Jackson School of Geosciences, established a community of geoscientists and educators across Texas to enhance diversity in geosciences and to improved geosciences literacy among Texas high school science teachers. The project built a collaborative network linking K-12 educators with leadership teams at fourteen regional DIG TEXAS hub institutions. The overarching goal of DIG Texas—to broaden diversity in the geosciences—requires that members of the alliance work cooperatively on multiple fronts to attract and support individuals from groups underrepresented in STEM fields to pursue earth science as a career.

Project outcomes include a community meeting held at the headquarters of Exxon Mobil in Houston, Texas in March 2011 at which participants identified three main goals:

a)     Strengthen Earth science education in Texas by getting the state’s capstone science course, Earth and Space Science (ESS), taught at the appropriate grade level by teachers who are properly prepared and aided by high quality resources.

b)    Identify ways to build on and leverage existing or recently supported federal- or state-sponsored projects to provide the training and resources needed by 8th grade and high school science teachers to successfully teach a 21st century Earth and Space Science, support the incorporation of additional institutions into the network, and engage other stakeholders and potential donors.

c)    Establish an interactive DIG Texas Web Site (Figure 1) with resources to support stakeholders, facilitate communication and serve as a repository for excellent exemplary teaching resources and curricula materials. In essence, the DIG Texas web site will provide stewardship for the content and services needed by the DIG Texas Alliance and promote collaboration on different fronts (sharing resources, best practices and joint proposals).

One outcome of activities undertaken by DIG Texas institutions to advance K-12 earth science literacy includes a new project sponsored by the NSF Geoscience Education Program to develop five online course road maps, or blueprints, for use in high school Earth and Space Science classes (Figure 2). Each blueprint will consist of an original earth science scope and sequence that documents what to teach, in what order, for how long, and, in the absence of a textbook, identifies which online resources to use of the thousands available. The Science Education Resource Center (SERC) at Carleton College is a partner on the project. Therefore, because of SERC's wide reach, we anticipate that the DIG Texas blueprints will have application beyond Texas in earth science classrooms in many states.

DIG Texas monitors State Board of Education activities in order to respond to initiatives or issues that affect K-12 earth science education. In July 2011, the Texas State Board for Educator Certification, considered the need to review teacher certifications for different subjects taught in Texas. DIG Texas leaders gave testimony in support of an earth science teacher certification.

DIG TEXAS seeks to broaden the community of stakeholders who are united by the alliance’s common vision through activities designed to nurture and promote collaboration among existing members; and by conducting outreach to prospective members.
